feedback.Physical object: Excluded — A proof is a formal abstraction, not a tangible thing.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Included — Formal proof is an invention of mathematical logic.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — Based on abstract reasoning, not biology.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — Proofs are not fixed entities; they are composed and can be revised.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — Structure is logical, not material.
feedback.Perceptible: Excluded — Not inherently perceivable without representation.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — A proof exists independently of any physical medium.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — Does not exhibit passive physical qualities.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — Constructed to demonstrate or derive a logical conclusion.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — Does not autonomously produce effects.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — Encodes logic but does not process it.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Excluded — Interpreted by humans, but not interactive itself.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Excluded — While used in systems (e.g., math), it is not a subsystem itself.
feedback.Autonomous in function: Excluded — Requires an interpreter or context to operate.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Not inherently critical to any system operation.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Proofs rely on symbolic language (e.g., logic notation).
feedback.Communicative: Included — Designed to convey formal truth or deduction.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — Derivation strictly follows logical rules.
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Included — Structured into premises, lemmas, and conclusions.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Included — Guides reasoning and deductive practices.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Included — Some proofs are about provability or logic itself.
feedback.Temporal: Included — Proofs follow a sequential logical progression.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — Meaning depends on formal system, axioms, and symbols used.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — The practice and validation of proof is socially defined.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Institutionalized in mathematics, philosophy, and CS.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Excluded — Not inherently tied to identity.
feedback.Regulated / governed: Excluded — Not subject to legal or institutional enforcement.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — Taught and learned in formal education.
feedback.Visible: Included — Proofs are commonly represented visually or textually.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Interpreted differently across logical systems.
feedback.Widely known: Included — Central to education, logic, and science.

encoding_notes: This encoding positions a logical proof as a fully abstract, intentional construct with formal structure and communicative purpose. It is symbolic, hierarchical, and deeply embedded in social and educational systems, but not a physical or functional actor on its own. The UHT code is identical to 'Concept of Zero' because both are fundamentally abstract tools with the same set of universal traits.
